Samantabhadra said:
Excellent question!
There are ten things for bodhisattvas to establish.
What are the ten?

Always aspiring to the Buddha, constantly contemplating the scriptures and Dharma, encouraging sentient beings to be transformed and abide in the Buddha's path, encouraging them to be at ease in their work, cultivating and establishing correct practices, conforming to and delighting in vows, always contemplating deportment, traveling at the right time, proclaiming the roots of goodness, and establishing the meaning of wisdom - these are the ten things for establishing the mind.
At that time, he spoke in verse:
Single-mindedly always contemplating the Buddha, diligently contemplating the scriptures,
Encouraging sentient beings to enter the path, showing them the deeds they have created.
Praising and assisting in the cultivation of correct practices, always causing them not to lose their vows,
Deportment and etiquette complete, the roots of goodness accomplish holy wisdom.
There are ten things for bodhisattvas to enjoy and believe in.
What are the ten?
The bodhisattva's mind gives rise to thoughts:
'In the future, when the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One appears in the world, I will see them all.
' Having seen the buddhas, he makes offerings and serves them, aspiring for the unsurpassed, bowing his head in surrender to these perfectly enlightened ones:
'You should instruct me, and through this instruction I will return to the bodhisattva stage, just as the bodhisattvas respectfully follow the teachings.
With a respectful mind, I will practice as I have heard.'
Then, the bodhisattva further thinks to himself:

'May I never be separated from the world-honored buddhas and bodhisattvas, and may I be able to eliminate the difficulties of running and escaping in birth and death, and cultivate bodhisattva practices for innumerable eons.'
He further thinks in his mind:

'In the past, before giving rise to the intention for the unsurpassed path, I was not yet a vessel of the Dharma. I feared the profound meaning, and also feared the slander and bad reputation of the world, and was afraid of the evil paths and assemblies in birth and death.
I am now free from this and will never unite with it again.
Because I am far away from it, wherever I am born, I will not be separated from the aspiration for the Way, and I will not be afraid, terrified, or anxious.
Forever free from difficulties, I will always be far from defilements;
Forever extinguishing impurities, I will come and go alone;
Subduing the many demons, I will eliminate the non-Buddhist paths.
Furthermore, he thought:
I will encourage and transform the realm of sentient beings, causing them to follow the precepts and aspire to the intention of the unsurpassed true Way, cultivating the practices of a bodhisattva.
When I attain Buddhahood, I will follow the sublime teachings of the Honored One and pay homage by respectfully taking refuge, with immeasurable joy, for as long as I live.

After the Buddha's parinirvÄá¹‡a, I will erect countless temples and shrines, serve the relics, uphold the Buddha's teachings, and distribute the scriptures, causing the unsurpassed meaning to endure forever.
Furthermore, he thought:
'I shall adorn the boundless world, making the Buddha-lands all pure and gentle, with various distinctions, equal and pure.
I shall move countless Buddha-lands, causing all to give rise to the intention [for enlightenment].
Emitting great light illuminating the ten directions, with spiritual powers and transformations reaching everywhere.'
He further thought:
'After I attain Buddhahood, I shall resolve the doubts of all beings and transform their minds, always keeping them pure and gentle.

Calming their thoughts, eliminating defilements and desires, blocking the doors to evil, opening the gates to eternal peace, removing darkness and obscurity, radiating great light, abandoning the work of Mara, and attaining supreme auspiciousness - with this merit I shall universally show it to all beings.'
He further thought:
'Wherever I am, I shall always see the Buddhas.
When in danger and distress, if I wish to pay homage and see them, I shall surely fulfill my wish and see the Right and Universal One, without being obstructed.
When directly seeing the TathÄgata expound the Dharma,
think: 'The TathÄgata is difficult to encounter, appearing only after countless eons, like a rare and auspicious flower.
' Give rise to a pure mind, abandon all improper thoughts, and be sincere and without flattery.
Furthermore, think in your mind:
'When I attain supreme, perfect enlightenment, I will manifest the Buddha's body in all buddha-lands to carry out buddha-work.

For the sake of sentient beings, I will beat the great Dharma drum, rain down the sweet dew of the Dharma, bestow the ultimate Dharma, be pure and fearless, roar the lion's roar, and make boundless vows.
Abiding in the Dharma realm, I will proclaim the scriptures.
Not resting for an eon, my body will not become weary;
my words will be inexhaustible, and my mind will not become tired.'
These are the ten things that the mind establishes.
At that time, he spoke in verse:
Adorning and purifying the lands of the buddhas, encouraging the path in sentient beings,
Demonstrating the profound and wondrous Dharma, causing them to give rise to the unsurpassed path.
Always wishing to see the buddhas, serving and taking refuge in them,
Listening and receiving the Dharma they expound, single-mindedly receiving and upholding it.
In order to sever the three evil destinies, opening the gate to peace and happiness;
For the sake of the dark and obscured, revealing the great bright light.
Propagating the Dharma of the sÅ«tras, eliminating all defilements;
Roaring like the great lion's roar, raining down the great sweet dew.
Bodhisattvas have ten kinds of profound Dharma.
What are the ten?
All enter the past events of the worlds, roaming in the profound Buddha Dharma with a determined mind;
Returning to the future events of the Buddha lands, being in all the Buddha lands and among the multitudes;
The correct enlightenment is non-dual, although being in the various lands it is presently tranquil;
The worldly customs and languages of the ten directions, the adornments and purity of the lands, he is able to know them all;
This is entering the profound Dharma, and in all lands there are various teachings;
He is also able to understand the different merits and demerits of all sentient beings, and the different practices of the bodhisattvas;

Moreover, the bodhisattva understands and knows the abodes of all the TathÄgatas of the past. The bodhisattva knows the speed of the teachings of all the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones. The bodhisattva also knows the Buddhas, the Perfectly Enlightened Ones, in the present lands, the holy assemblies of their retinues, the Dharma they expound, and the sentient beings they transform;
The Dharma realm is like empty space, without boundaries, and the TathÄgatas of the ten directions;
Moreover, he distinctly knows the worldly dharmas, the Å›rÄvaka dharmas, the pratyekabuddha vehicle, the bodhisattva, and the TathÄgata. Entering these dharmas, he has no desires;
He expounds the various dharmas he has entered, but there is nothing to enter and he does not conceptualize the Dharma. He follows the teachings of the dharmas and uses them to transform;
These are the ten matters of deeply entering the Buddha Dharma.
At that time, he spoke in verse:
Knowing the past, future, and present,
Following the customs of the world, manifesting the pure Buddha lands.
Distinguishing the sins and merits of people, the practices of the Bodhisattvas,
The present Buddha lands, and the assemblies of Bodhisattvas.
Knowing the number of sentient beings, speaking the Dharma with the limits of space,
Fully understanding the Shravakas, Pratyekabuddhas, and Bodhisattvas.
Bodhisattvas have ten things to rely on, and with these they cultivate the practices of Bodhisattvas.
What are the ten?

Always respectfully serving the Buddha, there is taking refuge, transforming sentient beings, seeing all good friends and relying on them, always delighting in accumulating the roots of virtue, also all adorning and purifying the Buddha lands, always having compassion for all and not abandoning sentient beings, universally entering all perfections, wishing to fulfill all bodhisattva vows, the immeasurable cultivation of the mind of returning to the path, and clearly understanding the Buddhas' attainment of perfect enlightenment. These are the ten things that the bodhisattvas rely on to accomplish the practice of the path.
At that time, he spoke in verse:
Respectfully serving the Buddhas, relying on the bodhisattva practices,
Transforming the various kinds of sentient beings, respectfully following the good friends,
Accumulating the roots of virtue, adorning and purifying the Buddha lands,
Entering the perfections, fulfilling the bodhisattva vows.
The bodhisattva's mind is courageous in ten ways.
What are the ten?
Eliminating all the offenses of the obscurations;
Although the buddhas, the world-honored ones, have entered nirvana, they still bestow their teachings;
With a courageous mind, they subdue the mÄras;
They understand impermanence;
They do not spare their bodies or lives, and through the power of the true Dharma, they subdue the non-Buddhists;
With a gentle mind, they delight and please sentient beings;
With a joyful intention, the assembly sees them and is not displeased;
They transform and tame all the devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, and mahoragas, who all receive their teachings;
They respectfully cultivate gentleness and rely on the profound Dharma;
They always abandon the stages of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, and for countless eons, they engage in the practices of bodhisattvas without becoming weary;
These are the ten courageous states of mind of the bodhisattvas.
Then, he spoke in verse:
Abandoning the hindrances, following the Buddha's teachings after his passing,
Subduing the mÄras, not sparing one's body or life,
Subduing and transforming the multitude of non-Buddhists, bringing joy to sentient beings,
Demons all receiving the teachings, always revering the practices of the Bodhisattva.
Bodhisattvas have ten things to cut off all doubts and prevent hesitation.
What are the ten?
Bodhisattvas give rise to the intention and think to themselves:
'I shall use giving, morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom to rescue and embrace sentient beings, and guide them with kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity.
Although I practice these, I have no doubts or hesitations, wanting to advance or retreat, it has never happened.'
They also think to themselves:

'I shall universally see the enlightened ones of the ten directions and the Buddhas of the future, encounter the unsurpassed wisdom, make offerings to the Buddhas, and not hesitate even a hair's breadth.'
Moreover, the Bodhisattvas think:
'Using various lights to fully illuminate the Buddha lands.
Hearing that the bodhisattvas of the future will practice for innumerable eons without becoming weary, and will teach and transform countless beings without considering it difficult,
They will contemplate the Dharma realm, which is immeasurable and boundless, like space;
The beings they will liberate will be equally numerous, without becoming weary or retreating.'
They will further think,
'Cultivating the bodhisattva practices, fulfilling all vows, and attaining the wisdom and spiritual powers of omniscience.'
They will also think,
'When practicing as a bodhisattva, may I attain the light of the Dharma and the supreme illumination of the Buddha.'
They should always consider all dharmas to be the Buddha's Dharma.
They will universally know the thoughts and intentions of beings, and will understand the innumerable, endless, unconditioned, and conditioned dharmas.

They will attain perfect enlightenment and clearly understand all dharmas, which are all beyond the world. They will eliminate inverted views and thoughts, and although there is defilement, the original nature is completely pure.
The bodhisattva understands all Buddha-Dharmas and attains supreme, correct enlightenment, without any false thoughts or inverted views, not attached to even a single hair.
Although the outflows are conditioned, one penetrates to the unconditioned, and abandons all gains and offerings, then one is able to enter the innumerable limits.
These are the ten matters by which the bodhisattva severs all doubts.
At that time, he spoke in verse:ğŸ”½Thinking of giving, precepts, patience, vigor,
Single-mindedness, cultivating wisdom,
Practicing loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, seeing all Buddhas and making offerings.
The light is fully illuminating, for innumerable future eons,
The mind is not lax, attaining the omniscience of Buddhahood.
All dharmas are Buddha-Dharmas, all are also Dharmas that transcend the world,
Abandoning defilement and inverted views, attaining the supreme, correct enlightenment of the Buddha.
The bodhisattva has ten inconceivable matters.
What are the ten?

The roots of virtue cultivated are inconceivable, and all vows are immeasurable. Observing all dharmas to be like illusions, one gives rise to the mind of the Way and relies on various wholesome karmas without any loss.

Cultivating bodhisattva practices is forever free from delusion. Cultivating profound and essential meanings, universally entering all dharmas, not attaining nirvana, and not abandoning the incomplete path wisdom.

When bodhisattvas practice the Way, they enter the womb, are born, accumulate diligent practices, go to the bodhi tree, subdue the mÄras, attain supreme perfect enlightenment, turn the Dharma wheel, manifest the attainment of nirvana, reveal the Buddha's activities, establish what is manifested, do not abandon great compassion, and protect all beings, not violating their original vows.

Moreover, the bodhisattvas establish and manifest the TathÄgata's ten powers, and from their initial arousal of the mind, in the Dharma realm, they transform and educate sentient beings without ever ceasing.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas enter into various thoughts with no thought, and enter into no thought with thought, speaking of various thought-related matters with no thought.
Moreover, they speak of no thought-related matters with various thoughts, and enter into existence with non-existence;

and various existences enter into non-existence. Transformations without action enter into transformations with action, and transformations with action enter into transformations without action. In the absence of attainment, they speak of attainment, and in the presence of attainment, they speak of non-attainment, understanding that all dharmas are ultimately non-existent.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas are impartial towards the Way, and with impartiality they understand that the Way and the minds of sentient beings are not different.
Their minds are not deluded or mistaken, their thoughts are never lost, they do not follow deviant doubts, and what they perceive is impartial.

Moreover, the bodhisattvas, in the time it takes to form a thought, their minds are tranquil, their minds are in samÄdhi, they abide in the ultimate reality without realizing it, and without any outflows they do not attain complete cessation.
Spreading the roots of virtue, understanding all dharmas, being without outflows, and expounding them for others; the outflows already exhausted, also proclaiming them for others.
One should eliminate the outflows, then using the Buddha Dharma to enter the worldly Dharma.
Although being within it, without worldly thoughts, without thoughts of worldly or non-worldly [dharmas].
Contemplating all dharmas, entering the Dharma body, yet without entering anything, understanding all dharmas as being non-dual and without activity.
These are the ten inconceivable [aspects] of the bodhisattva. The bodhisattva, abiding in this, quickly attains the unsurpassed true path.
The bodhisattva has ten things in expounding the truth.
What are the ten?
Expounding all Buddha Dharmas, according to the time, truly abandoning evil dharmas, without losing their principle.

Using the spiritual powers and transformations of the bodhisattvas to proclaim the teachings of the Right Enlightenment, able to enter the good and evil karmic actions of sentient beings according to their capacities, proclaiming to sentient beings.

Eliminating all dust and afflictive activities, they are able to understand the meaning of sentient beings and the Dharma gate of non-action, dissolving all obstructions and cultivating the practice of tranquility.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas have no abode, just like empty space.

In each entry, they do not uphold precepts. When heaven and earth are formed or destroyed, they have no hesitation. They are in the various worlds without hesitation, and in the realm of all dharmas, there are no obstructions.
In whatever direction they go, they benefit with subtlety, understanding the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, who has left home and finally attained nirvana.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas enter the Dharma realm and universally see the movements and activities of all buddhas.
The bodhisattvas see all kinds of sentient beings dwelling in nirvana, without any creation, vowing not to fall, and will certainly fully possess the wisdom of universal knowledge.
Moreover, there are bodhisattvas who see all dharmas as having nothing to rely on, and do not distance themselves from good friends or those who should be approached, nor do they become attached.
The TathÄgata's diligence is the Dharma of not being lax or resting, with a single standard of propriety.
Whether it be friends or enemies, he accumulates roots of virtue and encourages them to gather, all making them the same;
he praises and accomplishes without duality.
These are the ten matters of the bodhisattvas' constant timely explanations.
The bodhisattvas' discernment wisdom has ten aspects.
What are the ten?

Understanding all the buddha-lands, comprehending the decline and prosperity of the fundamental nature of sentient beings, discerning the presence of the mental activities of the masses, proclaiming the rise and fall of the faculties of the people, also knowing the results of the practices of all karmic retributions, universally entering the teachings of the Å›rÄvakas in accordance with the time, also lowering the practices of the pratyekabuddhas, all cultivating the bodhisattvas with skillful means, discerning all in accordance with worldly dharmas, all in accord with entering the buddhadharmas, understanding the wisdom that is appropriate - this is the bodhisattvas' ten kinds of discerning wisdom.
The bodhisattvas, abiding in this, quickly attain the unsurpassed true path.
There are ten things in the bodhisattvas' samÄdhi.
What are the ten things?
When in samÄdhi, knowing all that exists in the worlds in the ten directions;
Able to pacify the bodies of sentient beings with the mind in samÄdhi, and the samÄdhi of all dharmas;
In the samÄdhi of samÄdhi, seeing the buddhas in the ten directions, then able to establish all thoughts;
According to the time, the samÄdhi is determined. With the existence of samÄdhi, one can move and transform innumerable bodies, and also cause them to arise from samÄdhi;
Universally entering the buddhas, tathÄgatas, and samyak-saá¹ƒbuddhas;
Absorbed in samÄdhi, enlightening sentient beings;
With wisdom that is vast and all-encompassing, understanding the bodhisattva samÄdhis according to the time;
In a single thought, entering the wisdom of one-pointed concentration, with an unconditioned mind opening the wisdom of tranquility;
Universally able to cultivate the wisdom of all bodhisattvas, without abandoning firm faith;
With the great wisdom of vows, understanding samÄdhi;
These are the ten samÄdhis of the bodhisattva.
What do bodhisattvas possess? There are ten things.
What are the ten?
What do sentient beings possess?
The same is true for the lands;
Contemplating the multitude of sentient beings also understands their original non-existence;
When the eon is burned, heaven and earth perish, or there is a disaster of water;
After heaven and earth perish, they return to form and combine again;
Calculating the Buddha, the Right Enlightenment, also has no existence;
The various kinds of practices also have no location;
The TathÄgata's body has immeasurable merits;
All dharmas are explained with their respective meanings;
If one can make offerings to the Perfectly Enlightened Ones, there is also no return;
These are the ten things that bodhisattvas have.
Here is the verse:
Sentient beings have nothing, the lands have no location,
Observing the various marks and characteristics.
When the eon burns and the heavens and earth are destroyed, they return and combine in the same way.
The Buddha's body has various aspects, the TathÄgata is immeasurable, and he proclaims the Dharma in various aspects.
There are ten matters in the bodhisattva's liberation.
What are the ten?

Their bodies pervade all worlds, manifesting in the ten directions with innumerable forms and appearances, using the Dharma realms to enter a single buddha land, establishing the multitudes of all sentient beings, with the adornments of the buddhas pervading the ten directions and innumerable buddha lands, naturally awakening and reaching all realms, in a single thought pervading all buddha lands, manifesting all buddhas dwelling in a single land, causing all buddha realms to enter a single body, causing all buddhas to manifest their spiritual powers, and delighting in manifesting entry into a single thought. These are the ten doors of liberation for bodhisattvas.
Then he spoke in verse:
Their bodies pervade the buddha lands, manifesting innumerable forms and appearances;
The dharmas enter a single land, establishing the various worlds.
Pervading the world, manifesting the buddha body, knowing that there is nowhere it does not reach;
The dharmas enter a single essence, opening the minds of all people.
There are ten things about the spiritual powers of bodhisattvas.
What are the ten?
They are: knowing the past places they have been through, understanding the skillful means of entering, exiting, and advancing and retreating;
With the divine ear, they discern without obstruction, hearing all the words and the various destinations, and knowing the thoughts and actions of other beings;
With the divine eye, they observe all the various and different things that have occurred in the past;
With their great spiritual powers, they transform and establish inconceivable numbers of beings;
In accordance with their fundamental nature, they manifest and cause them to enter the precepts, seeing the limitless buddha-realms;
They manifest all bodies, and in the time it takes to arouse the mind, they can reach the immeasurable buddha-lands in the ten directions;
They are also able to adorn and establish countless realms;
They also manifest the complete physical form, without arrogance, understanding and penetrating wisdom;
In the country of Anti, he attained the unsurpassed true path and became the Most Supremely Enlightened One;
His mind is inconceivable, and he manifests and teaches according to the fundamental nature of sentient beings.

These are the ten meanings of the bodhisattvas' spiritual penetrations. If the bodhisattvas abide in this, they will attain the spiritual penetrations of the TathÄgata's unsurpassed true enlightenment, and will follow the skillful means to transform and manifest in the ten directions, teaching and transforming sentient beings, and will accomplish their practices and perfect the myriad meanings.
There are ten things in the bodhisattvas' spiritual penetrations.
What are the ten?

It means that he is able to teach and transform sentient beings according to the times, to distinguish their various different experiences of sin and merit, to cause them to leave the household life and to make their minds tranquil.
He enters into all obstructions, and causes the various different inverted practices of each sentient being to be eliminated, and he penetrates the holy wisdom like a vajra and fully establishes it.
His voice pervades inconceivably.
They teach in the buddha lands, understanding the skillful means, and all attachments and practices of the four immeasurable minds are universally entered.
They understand the place of birth and also clearly know that there is no place of birth, and have already removed all thoughts, feelings, and realms.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas do not contemplate dharmas, nor do they not contemplate them. Dharmas are without thought, considered to be one purity, and also without purity.
They illuminate various kinds, understand and know diligently, proclaim the Dharma for innumerable eons, and with equality return to the unsurpassed true path, always abiding in the Dharma realm.
Moreover, the bodhisattvas understand that all beings are originally extinguished, do not use worldly affairs, and have nothing to create. Knowing those who are born follow delusion.

Understanding the meaning of karmic causes and effects, they know what can be revered and respected. With what expedient means - the beginning and end of their practice, the place of arising and cessation - they distinguish and transform the various kinds of beings, illuminating the principle of the gate of liberation that opens and closes, and understanding their inverted and non-erroneous affairs.

They also know the source of desires, anger, and disputes, and also distinguish the karma of birth and death and of being free from fabrication. They also understand rebellious and non-rebellious affairs, and know those who can be relied upon and those who cannot.

They also clearly understand and distinguish the places they have reached - knowing those who have regressed and will return, knowing those who have reached certainty and their destination, and also knowing those who will be destroyed and will be reformed.

They also understand transformation, knowing the faculties of sentient beings, those who should be transformed and made to enter the precepts, and with various skillful means they teach the people without being confused or losing the practice of bodhisattvas.
Why is it so?
Buddha's disciples!
If you want to know why the bodhisattvas give rise to the mind of unsurpassed, true, and correct enlightenment,
Why is it so?
It is because they transform sentient beings. Having transformed sentient beings and caused them to follow the precepts, their bodies do not become weary.
This is the bodhisattvas' reason for being free from disputes for the sake of all, and it is the clear understanding and discernment of the twelve links of dependent arising.

Moreover, the bodhisattvas have never relied on the Buddha, nor have they given rise to the aspiration to rely on the Buddha. They are not attached to the Dharma, nor do they give rise to the desire for the Dharma. They are not attached to the Buddha-lands, nor do they give rise to the aspiration to rely on the Buddha-lands. They are not attached to people, nor do they give rise to the aspiration to delight in sentient beings. They do not see the people, nor do they give rise to the aspiration to contemplate the masses.

Giving rise to and manifesting various practices, fulfilling their vows, cultivating boundless compassion, not conceiving the view of the Buddha, and recollecting the Dharma that the TathÄgata has expounded.
Attaining the seat of the TathÄgata, planting various roots of virtue without becoming depressed, delighting in perfect enlightenment, not becoming weary or lax.

They also make offerings to the TathÄgata in accordance with the Dharma, and their minds become increasingly refined, moving and establishing inconceivable majestic spiritual powers in the worlds of all buddhas.

They establish the contemplation of the foremost Dharma realm, analyzing the teachings of various sÅ«tras, knowing the assemblies of conditioned beings, and also understanding the extent of the quantity of beings. They understand the beginning and end of suffering and from what it arises, and also know that all myriad things are ultimately suffering.

If there are bodhisattvas who can see this, their practice is also like a reflection, abandoning various evils and severing their roots, and they spontaneously give rise to the resolve to save and deliver beings.
What they practice is ultimately non-practice, called the practice of bodhisattvas, learning the words of all buddhas.

Their minds are firm and solid like Mount Sumeru, and they awaken to eliminate all inverted thoughts and establish the gateway of universal wisdom and spiritual penetrations, attaining perfect enlightenment and entering the hall of infinite wisdom without limit - what is called the hall of wisdom is the unsurpassed true path - they liberate sentient beings from the three realms of drifting and return to the source.
These are the ten things that bodhisattvas penetrate. Bodhisattvas abide in this and attain the TathÄgata's unsurpassed great wisdom.
There are ten things in the bodhisattva's liberation.
What are the ten?

They liberate from the source of afflictions and desires, free from the path of wrong views and unwholesomeness, and deliver from the suffering of the five aggregates' cover-ups. They also rescue from the four elements and various sense bases of the physical body, and transcend the vehicle of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas. Based on this, they attain the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, give rise to the appropriate dharmas of all sentient beings and lands, and then transcend the immeasurable bodhisattva practices. They praise all bodhisattva practices, enter the stage of the TathÄgata without conceptualization, and with a single holy wisdom universally know the three times. Their spiritual powers are impartial and they rescue all without exception. These are the ten liberations of the bodhisattvas.
The bodhisattvas abide in this and transform sentient beings, causing them to be unsurpassed.
At that time, he spoke in verse:
By transcending afflictions and desires, wrong views, and the five aggregates,
The four elements and various kinds, the suffering and difficulties of craving the body,
Surpassing the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, attaining the acceptance of non-arising,
Praising and uplifting sentient beings and the land, the bodhisattvas' immeasurable practices.
What the bodhisattvas cultivate, entering the ground of the TathÄgatas,
Surpassing all false thoughts, spiritually penetrating and understanding the three realms.
There are ten things in the bodhisattvas' garden.
What are the ten?
They enjoy birth and death, never disliking or wearying of it.
They delight in transforming sentient beings, their nature being unattached.
They dwell in the ground of all thoughts, initiating and receiving the great practices.
They always joyfully adorn and purify the buddhas' worlds, abiding in their own places.
Their resolve is to subdue the mÄras, concubines, and palaces, all able to transform them. Because of the palaces, terraces, and pavilions, they respect the Dharma that is taught.

As they hear the Dharma, they contemplate and understand the meaning, observing the ultimate six supernormal knowledges, the practices of embracing the four means of salvation, and the thirty-seven factors of the path and wisdom Dharma as the bodhisattvas' garden, which is their own majestic father's place of recreation.
The ten powers, four fearlessnesses, and eighteen distinctive abilities of the TathÄgata, in brief, all the Buddha's teachings are the garden for bodhisattvas.
